'''Terry Evans''' (born August 14, 1937)<ref name="Google"/> is an [[African American]] [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]], [[blues]], and [[soul music|soul]] singer, guitarist and songwriter.  He has worked with many musicians including [[Ry Cooder]], [[Bobby King]], [[John Fogerty]], [[Eric Clapton]], [[Joan Armatrading]], [[John Lee Hooker]], [[Boz Scaggs]], [[Maria Muldaur]] and [[Hans Theessink]].<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Char Ham |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/terry-evans-mn0000028275/biography |title=Terry Evans | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref><ref name="Evans"/>  Cooder stated that he always thought that Evans made a better "[[frontman]]."<ref name="Evans"/>

From 1994 to the present, Evans has released seven solo albums, including ''Blues for Thought'' (1994) ''Come to the River'' (1997) and ''Fire in the Feeling'' (2005).<ref name="AMG"/>

Evans career has been inspired by [[Elmore James]], [[Little Walter]], [[Albert King]], and [[B.B. King]].  Songs he has written have been recorded by [[Pops Staples]] and [[Louis Jordan]].<ref name="AMG"/>

==Life and career==
'''Terry Lee Evans'''<ref name="Google">{{cite book|url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6ZNfAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA232&dq=%22Terry+Evans%22.+%22BLUES%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Ozt0Urv7CtSshQfs5IDABg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Terry%20Evans%22.%20%22BLUES%22&f=false |title=Blues: A Regional Experience - Bob L. Eagle, Eric S. LeBlanc - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date=1937-08-14 |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref> was born in [[Vicksburg, Mississippi]], United States, and sang in his local church choir.<ref name="AMG"/>  His parents were keen for him to concentrate purely on [[gospel music]], although Evans found exposure to the work of mainstream blues musicians.<ref name="Evans">{{cite web|url=http://www.terryevansmusic.com/about.html |title=Terry Evans Music |publisher=Terry Evans Music |date= |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref>  He worked semi professionally with an [[a cappella]]  group called the Knights before relocating in the 1960s to [[Los Angeles]], [[California]].  He expanded his repertoire by learning to play the guitar and started to write songs for other musicians.  Amongst those who recorded his songs were Pops Staples ("Love Is a Precious Thing") and Louis Jordan ("Hop, Skip, and Jump"). Unable to find his own fame, despite television exposure, Evans teamed with fellow soul and gospel singer, [[Bobby King]]. They performed regularly on the [[chitlin' circuit]] throughout the 1970s, although Evans also worked as a [[backing vocalist]] for [[Ry Cooder]].  His backup work appeared on several of Cooder's albums down the years, including ''[[Chicken Skin Music]]'' (1976) and ''[[My Name Is Buddy]]'' (2007).<ref name="AMG"/> Evans joint work with King saw the release of two albums in 1988 and 1990.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1990-12-20/features/9004150235_1_star-soul-music-king-and-evans |title=Bobby King and Terry Evans Rhythm, Blues, Soul... - Chicago Tribune |publisher=Articles.chicagotribune.com |date=1990-12-20 |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref>

He gained a bigger audience through his involvement in the [[Crossroads (1986 soundtrack)|soundtrack]] to the 1986 [[film]], ''[[Crossroads (1986 film)|Crossroads]]''.  Evans voice appeared on the title track in the film itself, and on the soundtrack on another song, "Down in Mississippi".<ref name="Orange">{{cite web|author= |url=http://orangecityarts.net/event/onstage-orange-city-features-soul-blues-star-terry-evans/ |title=Onstage Orange City features soul & blues star Terry Evans - Orange City Arts Council|publisher=Orangecityarts.net |date=2013-06-17 |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref> Evans later worked with Lloyd Jones' on the latter's album, ''Trouble Monkey'', before recording his first solo album, ''Blues for Thought'' (1994).<ref name="AMG"/> It was [[record producer|produced]] by Ry Cooder, who also played guitar on the recording.<ref>{{cite web|author=Pemberton Roach |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/blues-for-thought-mw0000113526 |title=Blues for Thought - Terry Evans | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=1994-05-03 |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref> Evans sang backing vocals on the Dutch singer and guitarist [[Hans Theessink]]'s 1997 album, ''Journey On''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/journey-on-mw0000205290/credits |title=Journey On - Hans Theessink | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date=1997-04-28 |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=3E3pGRLc1L8C&pg=PA221&dq=%22TERRY+EVANS%22.+%22BLUES%22.+%22SOUL%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=FSgmUrKYK9CS7Ab-soHYDw&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22TERRY%20EVANS%22.%20%22BLUES%22.%20%22SOUL%22&f=false |title=More Blues Singers: Biographies of 50 Artists from the Later 20th Century - David Dicaire - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref> Evans 2001 album, ''Mississippi Magic'' was nominated for a [[Blues Music Award]] as the “Best Soul Blues Album of the Year”.<ref name="Orange"/> On Evans 2005 album, ''Fire in the Feeling'', [[David Lindley (musician)|David Lindley]] guest starred playing guitar on a couple of the tracks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crosscut.de/index.php?article_id=38&clang=1 |title=CrossCut Records | CCD 11086 TERRY EVANS Fire In The Feeling |publisher=Crosscut.de |date= |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref>

Evans most recent recording was his joint effort with Theessink, on ''Delta Time'' (2012). [[CBC News]] [[music journalism|journalist]], Bianca Cervantes, opined that "''Delta Time'' is the latest transatlantic blues treasure."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/new-album-delta-time-is-the-latest-transatlantic-blues-treasure-1.1346791 |title=New album 'Delta Time' is the latest transatlantic blues treasure - British Columbia - CBC News |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=2013-08-02 |accessdate=2013-11-02}}</ref>
